question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you donâ€™t find any error, mark â€˜No errorâ€™ as your answer.
Our neighbour / was always told us / funny jokes and stories.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 18 Nov S-1)
solution:
Answer: (a) was always told us

Explanation:
The error is in the phrase "was always told us". The verb form is incorrect here. The sentence should be in the active voice since the neighbour is the one doing the action.

Correct sentence:
"Our neighbour always told us funny jokes and stories."

Explanation of the error:

  • "Was told" is passive voice and doesnâ€™t fit with "us" as the object in this sentence structure.

  • The auxiliary "was" should be removed, and the verb changed to simple past tense "told".

Other parts are correct:

  • "Our neighbour" â€“ subject, correct.

  • "funny jokes and stories" â€“ object, correct.

Hence, the error is in "was always told us".

question:
The given sentence is divided into three segments. Select the option that has the segment with a grammatical error. If there is no error, select 'no error' as your answer.
Rosa will have / graduate from a reputed / university in 4 years.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 18 Nov S-2)
solution:
Answer: (c) graduate from a reputed
Explanation: The verb â€œgraduateâ€ should be in its past participle form when used with the future perfect tense â€œwill haveâ€.

  • Correct form: â€œwill have graduatedâ€ (not â€œwill have graduateâ€)
     Also, the word â€œreputedâ€ is often considered incorrect or awkward in modern English when referring to institutions. The better word is â€œprestigiousâ€ (à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§, à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤), though this is a style issue, not a grammar error.
     So, the corrected sentence should be: â€œRosa will have graduated from a prestigious university in 4 years.â€
     Other options:
     (a) â€œuniversity in 4 yearsâ€ â€“ correct âŒ
     (b) â€œNo errorâ€ â€“ incorrect because part (c) has an error âŒ
     (d) â€œRosa will haveâ€ â€“ correct beginning for future perfect tense âŒ
     âœ… Hence, the correct answer is: (c) graduate from a reputed.

question:
Choose the option that rectifies the grammatical errors in the given sentence.
The mason is building the house in the corner.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 18 Nov S-2)
option_1: The house in the corner is being build by the mason.
option_2: The house in the corner are being build by the mason.
option_3: The house in the corner is being built by the mason.
option_4: The house in the corner is being build to the mason.
solution:
Correct Answer:The house in the corner is being built by the mason.
Explanation:
 The original sentence is in the present continuous tense (is building), so its passive voice form should use the structure:
is/are being + past participle (V3)

Build (à¤¬à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾) â†’ built (V3 form)
"Is being built" is the correct passive form.
 Also, the subject "The house" is singular, so we use "is", not "are".
"By the mason" correctly shows the agent performing the action.

Correct passive sentence:The house in the corner is being built by the mason.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The doctors claim to discover / a cure for cancer, / and the medicine will be put / to test very soon.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 18 Nov S-2)
option_1: The doctors claim to discover
option_4: and the medicine will be put
solution:
Correct Answer:The doctors claim to discover
Explanation:
 The error lies in the use of "to discover".
 When talking about current or completed achievements, we use "to have discovered" instead of "to discover", which suggests a future or incomplete action.

Correct sentence:The doctors claim to have discovered a cure for cancer, and the medicine will be put to test very soon.

question:

question:

solution:
Explanation:

Correct Answer: carry milk

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been underlined and given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
The Dutta company hÌ²aÌ²sÌ² Ì²nÌ²oÌ²tÌ² bÌ²eÌ²iÌ²nÌ²gÌ² making new school bags sÌ²iÌ²nÌ²cÌ²eÌ² the lockdown cÌ²oÌ²mÌ²mÌ²eÌ²nÌ²cÌ²eÌ²dÌ².

question:
Identify the segment in the sentence which contains a grammatical error.
My friends are gone on a trip to Goa today.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 20 Apr S1 (9 to 10 AM))
solution:
Explanation:

Correct Answer: are gone

Whatâ€™s the grammatical issue?

  • Error Type: Incorrect auxiliary + past participle usage

  • Part of speech affected: Auxiliary verb ("are") + main verb ("gone")

ğŸ“˜ Rule: "Gone" vs. "Have gone"

  • âœ… Correct structure: â€œhave/has goneâ€ (Present Perfect)
    â†’ Used when someone has left and is still not back

  • âŒ Incorrect: â€œare goneâ€ in this context
    â†’ â€œare goneâ€ is passive-sounding and typically used for things that are missing or lost, not for people who have recently left on a trip

ğŸ” Correct Sentence:

â€œMy friends have gone on a trip to Goa today.â€

âŒ Evaluation of Other Segments:

  • My friends â€“ âœ… Correct plural subject

  • on a trip â€“ âœ… Correct prepositional phrase

  • to Goa today â€“ âœ… Correct destination and time modifier

ğŸŸ¢ So, the segment with the grammatical error is: â€œare goneâ€,

which should be replaced with â€œhave goneâ€ to form correct present perfect tense.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you donâ€™t find any error, mark â€˜No errorâ€™ as your answer.
This hall is / badly to need / of repair.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 20 Apr S1 (9 to 10 AM))
solution:
Explanation:

Correct Answer: badly to need

ğŸ” Whatâ€™s the grammatical issue?

  • Error Type: Incorrect verb structure (infinitive misuse)

  • Part of speech affected: Verb phrase ("to need")

ğŸ“˜ Explanation:

The phrase â€œbadly to needâ€ is grammatically incorrect and unnatural in English.
The correct idiomatic structure is:

"to be in bad need of repair"
or
"is badly in need of repair"

ğŸ” Corrected sentence:

âœ… â€œThis hall is badly in need of repair.â€

âœ” â€œbadlyâ€ (adverb) correctly modifies â€œin needâ€ (noun phrase)
âœ” Proper use of "in need of" construction

âŒ Evaluation of Other Segments:

  • This hall is â€“ âœ…
    âœ” Correct subject + auxiliary verb

  • of repair â€“ âœ…
    âœ” Correct phrase when paired with â€œin needâ€

  • No error â€“ âŒ
    âœ– There is an error in part 2

ğŸŸ¢ So, the segment with the grammatical error is: â€œbadly to needâ€,

which should be corrected to â€œbadly in needâ€.

question:

solution:
Explanation:

ğŸ”´ Error Type: Verb form error

[Subject] + are/is/was/were + V3 (past participle form)

  • The subject here is "Handicrafts" â†’ plural

  • The verb used is "are" â†’ present tense auxiliary (helping verb)

  • Therefore, it must be followed by a past participle (V3)

âŒ "export" is base form (V1) â†’ incorrect

"Handicrafts are exported from India to several European countries."

  • A. Handicrafts are â€“ âœ… Correct

Final Answer: B. export from India âœ…

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Will you / care for / a cup of / hot coffee?

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 20 Apr S3 (4 to 5 PM))
solution:
Explanation:

Correct Understanding:

The sentence is meant to be a polite offer, and in such cases, the correct form is:

â€œWould you care for...â€(à¤•à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤†à¤ª à¤²à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾ à¤šà¤¾à¤¹à¥‡à¤‚à¤—à¥‡...?)

So the phrase "Will you care for" is incorrect here.

ğŸ”¹ Error Type:

Incorrect modal verb for polite offering

ğŸ”¹ Part of Speech Involved:

Modal Verb Phrase â€“ â€œWill youâ€ should be â€œWould youâ€

ğŸ”¹ Why "Will you" is wrong:

  • "Care for" is a formal/polite expression used with "Would", not "Will".

  • "Will you care for" sounds unnatural and is not standard in polite offers.

ğŸ”¹ Other segments:

  • "care for" â€“ correct phrasal verb

  • "a cup of" â€“ grammatically correct

  • "hot coffee" â€“ correct adjective + noun combination

âœ… Final Answer: Will you

question:

question:

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Paul was / bited by a dog / when he / was a child.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 21 Apr S1 (9 to 10 AM))
solution:
âœ… Explanation:

Original sentence:
Paul was bited by a dog when he was a child.

ğŸ” Error Type:

Incorrect verb form (past participle)
Part of speech affected: Verb
Rule involved:
In passive voice with the auxiliary "was", the past participle of the verb must be used.
The correct past participle of "bite" is "bitten", not bited.

âŒ Incorrect usage:

Paul was bited by a dog â€“ âœ–
â€œbitedâ€ is not a valid verb form in English.

âœ… Correct usage:

Paul was bitten by a dog â€“ âœ”
Passive voice construction using the correct past participle of "bite."

âŒ Option-wise analysis (with Hindi meanings):

  • was a child â€“ âœ”
    No error. Simple past tense.
    (à¤œà¤¬ à¤µà¤¹ à¤¬à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¾ à¤¥à¤¾)

  • when he â€“ âœ”
    Correct. Used to introduce a time clause.
    (à¤œà¤¬ à¤‰à¤¸à¤¨à¥‡...)

  • Paul was â€“ âœ”
    Subject + auxiliary for passive structure.
    (à¤ªà¥‰à¤² à¤¥à¤¾...)

  • âŒ bited by a dog â€“ âœ–
    Wrong past participle. Should be bitten.
    (à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¨à¥‡ à¤•à¤¾à¤Ÿà¤¾ à¤—à¤¯à¤¾ â€“ bited à¤¨à¤¹à¥€à¤‚ à¤¹à¥‹à¤¤à¤¾, bitten à¤¸à¤¹à¥€ à¤¹à¥ˆ)

âœ… Correct sentence:
Paul was bitten by a dog when he was a child.

question:

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them contains an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options.
Mr. Rao asked the newcomer / to his office / if he will minded / working late that day.

option_1: Mr. Rao asked the newcomer

â€¢ The error is in the verb form â€œwill mindedâ€, which is grammatically incorrect.

â€¢ Also, â€œmindâ€ is the main verb, so its correct form is needed.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If there is no error, select â€˜No errorâ€™.
The balloon flew up / as soon as / the man cutting the string.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 23 August Shift 3 (3 to 4 PM))
option_3: the man cutting the string
solution:
Answer: the man cutting the string
Solution:
â€¢ The sentence is: "The balloon flew up / as soon as / the man cutting the string."
â€¢ The phrase â€œthe man cutting the stringâ€ is not a complete clause â€” it lacks a finite verb (i.e., a verb that shows tense).
â€¢ After the conjunction "as soon as", we need a proper clause with subject + verb (in past tense) to match the earlier part "The balloon flew up" (which is in simple past).
â€¢ So the correct form is: "the man cut the string"
â†’ Now both clauses are in simple past tense, making the sentence grammatically correct and logically complete.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them contains an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options.
All those students / who are participating / in the play / have been notify / to stay back for rehearsal / after 3:00 p.m.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 24 August Shift 2 (12 to 1 PM))
option_2: to stay back for rehearsal
solution:
Answer: have been notify
Solution:
â€¢ The phrase "have been notify" is grammatically incorrect.
â€¢ After "have been", we need the past participle form of the verb.
â€¢ The correct past participle of "notify" is "notified".

Correct phrase:"have been notified"

Correct sentence:
"All those students who are participating in the play have been notified to stay back for rehearsal after 3:00 p.m."

Grammar rule:
After "have been", always use the past participle form of the main verb.
â€“ notify â†’ notified
â€“ complete â†’ completed
â€“ inform â†’ informed

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The manager told her that / she should be a bit more / careful while executed the / orders of the company.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 3 Dec Shift-3)
option_1: she should be a bit more
option_3: The manager told her that
solution:
Answer: careful while executed the

Explanation:

  • After â€œwhile,â€ we use the present participle (verb+â€“ing) to show an action happening at the same time.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
She will have participate / in the dance competition / by the time her father / returns from the tour.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 3 Oct Shift-1 (9 to 11 AM))
option_2: by the time her father
solution:
The segment that contains a grammatical error is: â€œShe will have participateâ€

The error lies in the use of the verb "participate" in the future perfect tense. In English, when expressing an action that will be completed by a certain time in the future, we use the future perfect tense, which involves the auxiliary verb "have" and the past participle of the main verb.

The correct form of the verb in this context is "participated" as it is the past participle of "participate." The corrected sentence would be: "She will have participated in the dance competition by the time her father returns from the tour."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
There are more than two million / job-seekers who are already / completed their fitness test / for the post since 2020.

(SSC SP Ph-11 : 30 June Shift-1 )
option_1: There are more than two million
solution:
The correct answer is job-seekers who are already

Here we use have in place of are.

The correct sentence would be â€œThere are more than two million job-seekers who have already completed their fitness test for the post since 2020.â€

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
â€œYou look so young! / When did you completed your graduation?â€ / asked Rekha / to her neighbour.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 4 Oct Shift-1 (9 to 11 AM))
option_4: When did you completed your graduation?
solution:
The segment that contains a grammatical error is: When did you completed your graduation?
The correct form should be "When did you complete your graduation?" The verb "complete" should be in its base form after the auxiliary verb "did." So, the corrected sentence would be: "When did you complete your graduation?"

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Mr. Khanna and family / have visit / Manali during / the summer vacation.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 4 Oct Shift-2 (12_30 to 2_30 PM))
solution:
The correct answer will be: have visit
It should be corrected to: "have visited"
Verb Form: The verb "visit" is in the incorrect form in the sentence. The base form of the verb "visit" is "visit," but in the present perfect tense, it should be conjugated as "visited."
Therefore, the corrected segment is: "Mr. Khanna and family have visited Manali during the summer vacation."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The university has putting off / the semester examination / for the second time now / due to technical issues.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 4 Oct Shift-2 (12_30 to 2_30 PM))
option_1: The university has putting off
option_3: for the second time now
solution:
The segment that contains a grammatical error is: "The university has putting off"
The correct form should be: "The university has been putting off"
The error lies in the verb form. The verb "has" requires a participle form after it to form the present perfect tense. In this case, the participle form "been putting off" should be used to indicate the ongoing action of postponing the semester examination.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you donâ€™t find any error, mark â€˜No errorâ€™ as your answer.
I was wish / to meet her / on her birthday.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 4 Oct Shift-3 (4 to 6 PM))
solution:
The error is in part A: "I was wish." The correct form should be "I wish."
So the corrected sentence would be: "I wish / to meet her / on her birthday."
The verb "was" is in the past tense, but it's not necessary in this context. When expressing a desire or intention, we typically use the base form of the verb "wish." So the correct form here would be simply "I wish."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
We have being / arranged the stay / for the guests at / a hillside resort.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 4 Oct Shift-3 (4 to 6 PM))
solution:
The segment that contains a grammatical error is: "We have being"
The correct form should be: "We have been"
The correct form should be "We have been." "Being" is the present participle form of the verb "to be," but in this context, the past participle form "been" is required because it's used in conjunction with the auxiliary verb "have" to form the present perfect tense. So the corrected form should be "We have been."
So the corrected sentence is: "We have been arranged the stay for the guests at a hillside resort."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
It is take / a couple of minutes / for the computer / to boot up.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 4 Oct Shift-3 (4 to 6 PM))
solution:
The segment that contains a grammatical error is: It is take
The subject of the sentence is "It," and the verb that should agree with it is "takes" (singular form of the verb "take"). However, in the given sentence, the verb form "is take" is incorrect. The correct form should be "takes," which is the third-person singular form of the verb "take."
So, the corrected sentence would be: "It takes a couple of minutes for the computer to boot up."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
I will celebrating New Year at my old residence as usual.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 4_Sept_Shift-3)
option_2: at my old residence as usual.
solution:
Answer: 4
Solution: The error is in the segment "will celebrating".

The correct future tense construction should be "will celebrate" (base verb after "will").

Correct sentence:
"I will celebrate New Year at my old residence as usual."

Other segments are grammatically correct.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you donâ€™t find any error, mark â€˜No errorâ€™ as your answer.
My elder brother / yesterday had took / my Facebook password.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 5 Oct Shift-1 (9 to 11 AM))
solution:
The error is in part (b): "yesterday had took."

The correct past tense form of the verb "take" is "took," and had should not come here.

So, the correct form of the sentence should be: "My elder brother yesterday took my Facebook password."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you donâ€™t find any error, mark â€˜No errorâ€™ as your answer.
We will / have been know the result / of the CAT exam by next week.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 5 Oct Shift-1 (9 to 11 AM))
option_3: have been know the result
option_4: of the CAT exam by next week
solution:
The phrase "have been know" is grammatically incorrect. The correct construction is "have known."

The correct phrase should be "have known the result" instead of "have been know the result."

Therefore, the corrected sentence would be: "We will have known the result of the CAT exam by next week."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you donâ€™t find any error, mark â€˜No errorâ€™ as your answer.
I am sure Helena / would passes / with flying colours.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 5 Oct Shift-2 (12_30 to 2_30 PM))
solution:
The part that contains the error is: b) would passes

The error in the given sentence lies in the verb form "passes." When using "would" as a modal verb to indicate a future possibility or hypothetical situation, the base form of the main verb should follow it. In this case, the correct form of the verb is "pass" (base form) rather than "passes"

So, the corrected sentence is: "I am sure Helena would pass with flying colours."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been underlined and given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
HÌ²aÌ²vÌ²eÌ² they bÌ²eÌ²eÌ²nÌ² wÌ²oÌ²rÌ²kÌ² in that particular shop fÌ²oÌ²rÌ² several years?

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 5 Oct Shift-3 (4 to 6 PM))
solution:
The error is in option C: "wÌ²oÌ²rÌ²kÌ²." The correct form should be "worked."

The error in the sentence lies in the form of the verb "work." In this context, "work" should be in the past participle form, which is "worked," to form the present perfect tense.

Therefore, the correct sentence should be: "Have they been worked in that particular shop for several years?"

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains an error.
Did / her friend / went to / school yesterday?

(SSC MTS 2023 : 5_Sept_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: Option 1 â€“ went to

Solution:

The sentence is:
"Did / her friend / went to / school yesterday?"

Letâ€™s understand the rule:

  • When a sentence begins with "Did" (simple past interrogative), the main verb must be in its base form (V1).

  • Here, "Did" is already showing the past tense, so the main verb should not be in past form ("went") but rather in its base form "go".

Correction:

  • âŒ "Did her friend went to school yesterday?" â†’ Incorrect

  • âœ… "Did her friend go to school yesterday?" â†’ Correct

So, the error lies in "went to" â€“ it should be "go to".

Therefore, the incorrect segment is Option 1 â€“ went to.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been underlined and given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
I wÌ²iÌ²lÌ²lÌ² Ì²gÌ²oÌ²iÌ²nÌ²gÌ² oÌ²nÌ² aÌ²nÌ² Ì²oÌ²fÌ²fÌ²iÌ²cÌ²iÌ²aÌ²lÌ² Ì²tÌ²oÌ²uÌ²rÌ² nÌ²eÌ²xÌ²tÌ² Ì²wÌ²eÌ²eÌ²kÌ².Ì²

(SSC MTS 2023 : 5_Sept_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: Option 1 â€“ will going

Solution:

The sentence is:
"I will going on an official tour next week."

This is grammatically incorrect because:

  • The modal "will" is followed by the base form of the verb (V1), not the present participle (V+ing).

  • So, "will going" âŒ is wrong.

  • The correct structure is: "will go" âœ…

Correct sentence:

"I will go on an official tour next week."

So, the error lies in "will going", which should be "will go" â€“ Option 1.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
When the train pulled in / at the station, it take / Joseph some time / to get off.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 6 Dec Shift-3)
option_3: at the station, it take
option_4: When the train pulled in
solution:
Answer: at the station, it take

Explanation:

  • The sentence is in the past tense (â€œpulledâ€), so the main verb must also be past.

  • â€œtakeâ€ (present tense) is incorrect here. It should be â€œtookâ€ to match the past context.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into four parts. Identify the part that contains an error.
(A) The mother exclaimed / (B) when she saw her son / (C) stumble on the race track, / (D) â€œLook, he fells!â€

(SSC MTS 2023 : 6_Sept_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: (1) D
Solution:
â€¢ The error is in part D: â€œLook, he fells!â€ â€“ the verb "fells" is incorrect
â€¢ "Fell" is the past tense of "fall", and the correct simple present tense is "falls"
â€¢ In direct speech, especially exclamations like "Look, he ___!", we use the present tense if the action is happening at the moment
â€¢ "Fells" is actually a different verb meaning "to cut down (a tree)" or "to knock someone down", which does not fit here
â€¢ Therefore, â€œLook, he fells!â€ should be corrected to â€œLook, he falls!â€
â€¢ Corrected sentence: The mother exclaimed when she saw her son stumble on the race track, â€œLook, he falls!â€

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The boy had run away / because he couldnâ€™t stand / his father beat him / for one more day.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 7 Dec Shift-1)
option_4: The boy had run away
solution:
Answer: his father beat him

Explanation:
After â€œcouldnâ€™t stand,â€ the verb must be in the -ing form. It should read:

â€¦because he couldnâ€™t stand his father beating him for one more day.

Thus, the segment â€œhis father beat himâ€ is incorrect.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
Ishita will playing Tennis for her favourite team.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 8_Sept_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: (2) will playing
Solution:
â€¢ The phrase "will playing" is grammatically incorrect
â€¢ After "will", we should use the base form of the verb (infinitive without "to"), not the "-ing" form
â€¢ Correct phrase is "will play"

Correct sentence:
"Ishita will play tennis for her favourite team."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you donâ€™t find any error, mark â€˜No errorâ€™ as your answer.
You may discussing / your problem / in tomorrowâ€™s meeting.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (8 Mar))
solution:
The error in the sentence lies in the use of the verb form after the modal verb "may". In English grammar, modal verbs like "may", "can", "should", "will", etc., are always followed by the base form of the main verb (also called the infinitive without "to"). In the given sentence, the word "discussing" is the present participle form of the verb "discuss", which is incorrect after a modal verb.

Hence, instead of "You may discussing", the correct form should be "You may discuss".

Therefore, the grammatically correct sentence is:
"You may discuss your problem in tomorrowâ€™s meeting."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Imagine taking a trip to Northern India / a century or so before the Common Era / using the recently discovering technology / of time travel.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (8 Mar))
option_1: using the recently discovering technology
option_2: Imagine taking a trip to Northern India
option_4: a century or so before the Common Era
solution:
The sentence is:

Imagine taking a trip to Northern India / a century or so before the Common Era / using the recently discovering technology / of time travel.

Letâ€™s examine the segments:

  • "Imagine taking a trip to Northern India" â€“ Correct. The verb usage is appropriate.

  • "a century or so before the Common Era" â€“ Also correct. This is a time reference and grammatically fine.

  • "using the recently discovering technology" â€“ Incorrect. The word "discovering" is the present participle (verb form), which is wrong here.

  • It should be "discovered", as in "recently discovered technology", which is a passive construction describing something that has been found.

  • "of time travel" â€“ Correct. It correctly connects the object "technology" with its purpose.

So, the error lies in the third segment, due to the incorrect use of "discovering" instead of "discovered."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
It is estimating that this forest once covered an area of approximately 400 km.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (8 Mar))
solution:
The error lies in the segment: "It is estimating that".

  • The verb "is estimating" is in the present continuous tense, which is incorrect when the sentence talks about a past situation ("this forest once covered...").

  • The correct passive structure should be: "It is estimated that..."

So, the correct sentence should be:
"It is estimated that this forest once covered an area of approximately 400 km."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
The Board of Directors held a meeting sorting out the issue of the NPAs of the bank.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (8 Mar))
option_1: the NPAs of the bank.
option_2: The Board of Directors held
solution:
The error lies in the phrase "a meeting sorting out".

  • The sentence structure requires a relative clause to properly connect the meeting and its purpose.

  • The correct form should be: "a meeting to sort out" or "a meeting that sorted out", rather than "a meeting sorting out", which is grammatically awkward and unclear.

Correct sentence:
The Board of Directors held a meeting to sort out the issue of the NPAs of the bank.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you donâ€™t find any error, mark â€˜No errorâ€™ as your answer.
Her parents did not allowed her to learn western music.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (8 Mar))
solution:
The error lies in the use of the verb form after the auxiliary 'did'.

  • After "did", the base form of the verb should be used.

  • The sentence says: "did not allowed" â€“ here, "allowed" is the past form, which is incorrect.

  • The correct structure is: "did not allow" (base form after 'did').

Letâ€™s check the parts:

  • Part 1: "Her parents" â€“ correct subject.

  • Part 2: "did not allowed her" â€“ incorrect; should be "did not allow her".

  • Part 3: "to learn western music" â€“ grammatically correct.

Correct sentence: Her parents did not allow her to learn western music.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Akasa Air planning to acquire / 150 Boeing 737 planes in order to / expand the airline's reach in / both domestic and international operations.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (8 Mar))
option_1: 150 Boeing 737 planes in order to
option_2: Akasa Air planning to acquire
option_3: both domestic and international operations
option_4: expand the airline's reach in
solution:
The error lies in the segment: "Akasa Air planning to acquire".

  • This part is missing an auxiliary verb. To form the correct present continuous or future intention structure, it should be:

  • "Akasa Air is planning to acquire" (present continuous)

  • OR "Akasa Air plans to acquire" (simple present for general future plan)

Hence, the sentence should begin as:
"Akasa Air is planning to acquire..."

Other segments are grammatically correct:

  • â€œ150 Boeing 737 planes in order toâ€ â€“ Correct phrase indicating purpose.

  • â€œexpand the airlineâ€™s reach inâ€ â€“ Grammatically fine.

  • â€œboth domestic and international operations.â€ â€“ Correct parallel construction.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you donâ€™t find any error, mark â€˜No errorâ€™ as your answer.
She use to eat / a lot of chocolates / when she was a child.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (8 Mar))
option_3: when she was a child
solution:
Explanation:

The original sentence part: "She use to eat" is grammatically incorrect.

  • The correct form is "used to", not "use to", when talking about past habits.

  • "Used to" is a fixed expression used to indicate an action that was regularly done in the past but no longer happens.

Correct sentence:

"She used to eat a lot of chocolates when she was a child."
